trans-unit.source: ms.assetid: 08C8F359-E8B6-4A45-8F4B-8A1962F0CE38 description: Microsoft Visual Studio is to Windows as Xcode is to iOS and Mac OS.
trans-unit.target: ms.assetid: 08C8F359-E8B6-4A45-8F4B-8A1962F0CE38 description: Microsoft Visual Studio is to Windows as Xcode is to iOS and Mac OS.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, we help you get comfortable using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, we help you get comfortable using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: title: Getting started: Creating a project
trans-unit.target: title: Getting started: Creating a project

trans-unit.source: Getting started: Creating a project
trans-unit.target: Getting started: Creating a project

trans-unit.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)

trans-unit.source: Creating a project
trans-unit.target: Creating a project

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Visual Studio is to Windows as Xcode is to iOS and Mac OS.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Visual Studio is to Windows as Xcode is to iOS and Mac OS.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, we help you get comfortable using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, we help you get comfortable using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: It shows you the absolute basics you'll need to know to get started.
trans-unit.target: It shows you the absolute basics you'll need to know to get started.

trans-unit.source: Each time you create an app, you'll follow steps similar to these.
trans-unit.target: Each time you create an app, you'll follow steps similar to these.

trans-unit.source: The following video compares Xcode and Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: The following video compares Xcode and Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: One dev minute - Comparing Xcode to Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: One dev minute - Comparing Xcode to Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Creating an app for Windows 10 (more formally referred to as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app) is rather like creating an iOS app using Storyboard.
trans-unit.target: Creating an app for Windows 10 (more formally referred to as a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app) is rather like creating an iOS app using Storyboard.

trans-unit.source: The Windows 10 app is often constructed over several pages, each page containing a different part of the user interface, like a web site.
trans-unit.target: The Windows 10 app is often constructed over several pages, each page containing a different part of the user interface, like a web site.

trans-unit.source: Each page has two associated source files: one to store the user interface defined either programmatically or visually, stored in [XAML overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt185595) format, and one that contains the source code.
trans-unit.target: Each page has two associated source files: one to store the user interface defined either programmatically or visually, stored in [XAML overview](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt185595) format, and one that contains the source code.

trans-unit.source: As your user interacts with your app, they will navigate between these pages.
trans-unit.target: As your user interacts with your app, they will navigate between these pages.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, you will create an app with two pages.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, you will create an app with two pages.

trans-unit.source: **Note** An important feature of Windows 10 apps is the fact that the same source code, and the same API set, is available to you no matter the platform.
trans-unit.target: **Note** An important feature of Windows 10 apps is the fact that the same source code, and the same API set, is available to you no matter the platform.

trans-unit.source: As you know, when you are writing a universal iOS app for iPhone and iPad, you can determine at run-time which platform your app is running on, and take the appropriate action.
trans-unit.target: As you know, when you are writing a universal iOS app for iPhone and iPad, you can determine at run-time which platform your app is running on, and take the appropriate action.

trans-unit.source: In a similar way, Windows 10 apps can tell, at run-time, the device they are running on.
trans-unit.target: In a similar way, Windows 10 apps can tell, at run-time, the device they are running on.

trans-unit.source: With a UWP app, there is no need to use \#ifdef's in your source code to create phone versus desktop builds.
trans-unit.target: With a UWP app, there is no need to use \#ifdef's in your source code to create phone versus desktop builds.

trans-unit.source: Conveniently, Windows 10 apps also intelligently use their user interface controls depending on the device: for example, your app may reference a date picker control, and the control will automatically look and function differently depending on whether it's running on a desktop or a phone screen.
trans-unit.target: Conveniently, Windows 10 apps also intelligently use their user interface controls depending on the device: for example, your app may reference a date picker control, and the control will automatically look and function differently depending on whether it's running on a desktop or a phone screen.

trans-unit.source: Your source code, however, remains the same.
trans-unit.target: Your source code, however, remains the same.

trans-unit.source: Let's see how we can create a Windows 10 app.
trans-unit.target: Let's see how we can create a Windows 10 app.

trans-unit.source: Start by running Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Start by running Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: The first time you run it, Visual Studio will ask you to get a developer license.
trans-unit.target: The first time you run it, Visual Studio will ask you to get a developer license.

trans-unit.source: A developer license lets you install and test Windows Store apps on your local computer before you submit them to the Windows Store.
trans-unit.target: A developer license lets you install and test Windows Store apps on your local computer before you submit them to the Windows Store.

trans-unit.source: To get a license, follow the on-screen directions to sign in with a Microsoft account.
trans-unit.target: To get a license, follow the on-screen directions to sign in with a Microsoft account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have one, click the **Sign up** link in the **Developer License** dialog box, and follow the on-screen directions.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have one, click the **Sign up** link in the **Developer License** dialog box, and follow the on-screen directions.

trans-unit.source: For comparison, when you start Xcode, the first thing you see is the **Welcome to Xcode** screen, similar to the following figure.
trans-unit.target: For comparison, when you start Xcode, the first thing you see is the **Welcome to Xcode** screen, similar to the following figure.

trans-unit.source: xcode welcome screen
trans-unit.target: xcode welcome screen

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio is very similar.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio is very similar.

trans-unit.source: You'll see the **Start Page**, as shown in the following figure.
trans-unit.target: You'll see the **Start Page**, as shown in the following figure.

trans-unit.source: visual studio start screen
trans-unit.target: visual studio start screen

trans-unit.source: To create a new app, start by making a project by doing one of the following:
trans-unit.target: To create a new app, start by making a project by doing one of the following:

trans-unit.source: In the **Start** area, tap **New Project**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Start** area, tap **New Project**.

trans-unit.source: Tap the **File** menu, and then tap **New Project**.
trans-unit.target: Tap the **File** menu, and then tap **New Project**.

trans-unit.source: For comparison, when you create a new project in Xcode, you see a list of project templates like those shown in the following figure.
trans-unit.target: For comparison, when you create a new project in Xcode, you see a list of project templates like those shown in the following figure.

trans-unit.source: xcode new project dialog box
trans-unit.target: xcode new project dialog box

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, there are also several project templates to choose from, as shown in the following figure.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, there are also several project templates to choose from, as shown in the following figure.

trans-unit.source: visual studio new project dialog box](images/ios-to-uwp/ios-to-uwp-vs-choose-template.png) For this walkthrough, tap **Visual C#**, and then tap **Windows**, **Windows Universal** and **Blank App (Windows Universal)**.
trans-unit.target: visual studio new project dialog box](images/ios-to-uwp/ios-to-uwp-vs-choose-template.png) For this walkthrough, tap **Visual C#**, and then tap **Windows**, **Windows Universal** and **Blank App (Windows Universal)**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Name** box, type "MyApp", and then tap **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Name** box, type "MyApp", and then tap **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio creates and then displays your first project.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio creates and then displays your first project.

trans-unit.source: Now, you can begin to design your app and add code to it.
trans-unit.target: Now, you can begin to design your app and add code to it.

trans-unit.source: Next step
trans-unit.target: Next step

trans-unit.target: Getting started: Choosing a programming language
